text: I opened the ledger and looked up. “Are you booking a room for Lucia as well?”
“Yes. She’ll be helping me sort the herbs tonight.”
“The room next door is quiet. The wind doesn’t reach much there.” I handed her the two keys.
As she took the keys, her gaze lingered briefly on my fingers—soft, and strangely gentle.
“Master! I’ll go get the room ready!”
“Don’t touch the window sill!”
Lucia ran upstairs with her basket of herbs, her footsteps light as wind chimes. Alicia watched her go and let out a quiet sigh.
“Your apprentice is quite adorable.”
“She’s a good child—luckier than I ever was. I found her in a war-torn village when she was ten.”
Her voice dropped slightly, as though afraid to disturb some long-buried memory.
“And her family…?”
“Gone.” She paused, her fingers tracing the edge of the key. “When I found her, she was clutching a broken lantern, still waiting for someone to come back.”
The fire cast a faint glow across her armor. The air was so still that only the crackling of wood could be heard.
“Since then, she’s stayed by my side. Mixing herbs, marking roads, asking questions... just like now.”
“You think of her as family, don’t you?”
“Maybe.” A faint smile crossed her lips. “But sometimes I think... she understands life better than I do.”
I didn’t know what to say. The firelight flickered in her eyes, and that soft smile carried a trace of sorrow almost too delicate to name.
“I should get some rest.”
“The air feels damp. It might snow again tonight.”
“I’ll keep dinner for you both.”
“Thank you.”
“There’s something about this place... it feels strangely familiar.”
Her footsteps were almost soundless as she went upstairs.
I watched her go, feeling a quiet ache in my chest.
Then I looked down—and saw the brass die lying quietly on the counter again.
Outside, the wind brushed past the eaves, carrying the faint toll of a distant church bell.
For a moment, it felt as if time itself had shifted slightly—like someone, somewhere, had just turned a hidden gear.
